{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox person |name = Richard J. Pratt |image = Richard Pratt.jpg |caption = Pratt in 1997 |birth_date = {{Birth date|1934|12|10|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Free City of Danzig]] (present-day [[Gdańsk|Gdańsk, Poland]]) |birth_name = Ryszard Przecicki |death_date = {{Death date and age|2009|04|28|1934|12|10|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Kew, Victoria]], Australia |other_names = Ryszard Przecicki |known_for = Businessman
President of the
[[Carlton Football Club]] |networth = [[A$]]5.48 billion (2009){{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/10/billionaires-2009-richest-people_Richard-Pratt_2AFB.html |title=#468 Richard Pratt - The World's Billionaires 2009 |website=Forbes.com |date=11 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160611165544/http://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/10/billionaires-2009-richest-people_Richard-Pratt_2AFB.html|archivedate=11 June 2016|deadurl=no |accessdate=15 September 2016}} |spouse = Jeanne Lasker |children = Four |nationality = Australian }} '''Richard J. Pratt''' (born '''Ryszard Przecicki'''; 10 December 1934{{spaced ndash}}28 April 2009{{cite news|last=Schulz|first=Matthew|title=Life and times of Richard Pratt|publisher=News Limited|newspaper=Herald Sun|date=28 April 2009|url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25366289-2862,00.html|accessdate=28 April 2009|archivedate=2 May 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502004819/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25366289-2862,00.html}}) was a prominent Australian businessman, chairman of the privately owned company [[Visy Industries]], and a leading figure of [[Melbourne]] society. In the year before his death Pratt was Australia's fourth-richest person, with a personal fortune valued at {{A$|5.48}} billion.{{cite news|last=Chappell|first=Trevor|title=Alan Bond makes BRW rich list comeback|work=Australian Associated Press|publisher=News Limited|date=28 May 2008|url=http://www.news.com.au/business/story/0,23636,23772566-462,00.html|accessdate=29 April 2009|archivedate=20 February 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220132140/http://news.com.au/business/story/0,23636,23772566-462,00.html}} ==Early life== Ryszard Przecicki was born in the Free City of Danzig (present-day [[Gdańsk|Gdańsk, Poland]]) to [[Jewish]] parents Leon and Paula on 10 December 1934.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/inquirer/the-great-enabler/story-e6frg6z6-1225704689901|title=Richard Pratt, the great enabler|newspaper=The Australian|date=29 April 2009|publisher=News Limited|access-date=29 November 2016}} His family immigrated to Australia in 1938 seeking safe refuge from the Nazis and settled in [[Shepparton, Victoria]], changing their surname from Przecicki to Pratt. Pratt had a rough journey travelling to Australia without getting caught by the Nazis. The family faced food shortages en route. Pratt was educated at Grahamvale Primary School, [[Shepparton High School]] and [[University High School, Melbourne|University High School]] and enrolled in a Bachelor of Commerce degree at the [[University of Melbourne]] in 1953.{{cite web|url=http://www.unimelb.edu.au/ExecServ/honcausa/citation/pratt.html|accessdate=17 March 2007|title=Richard Pratt profile|year=2004|publisher=University Secretary's Office, [[University of Melbourne]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060829195748/http://www.unimelb.edu.au/ExecServ/honcausa/citation/pratt.html|archivedate=29 August 2006}} He played [[Australian rules football]], as a ruckman. After starting his career at Lemnos (now the [[Shepparton Swans Football Club|Shepparton Swans]]), Pratt played for [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] in the [[Victorian Football League (1897–1989)|Victorian Football League]]'s (VFL) under-19s competition. He was awarded the [[Morrish Medal]] in 1953 for being deemed the "[[best and fairest]]" U-19 player that year.{{cite web|title=Morrish Medal|work=AFL|publisher=Bigpond|url=http://www.afl.com.au/morrish%20medal/tabid/270/default.aspx|accessdate=28 April 2009}} Pratt did not continue his footballing career to senior VFL level, instead focusing on other interests.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Pratt combined study with acting with the [[Melbourne Theatre Company|Union Theatre Repertory Company]] and working as salesman for the family business, [[Visy Industries|Visy Board]]. After touring London and New York in 1957 with a production of [[Ray Lawler]]'s ''[[Summer of the Seventeenth Doll]]'', playing the role of Johnnie Dowd, he returned to Melbourne and Visy. Following the death of his father Leon in February 1969 Pratt took over his father's business, which at that time had several hundred employees and an annual turnover of [[Australian dollar|A$]]5 million.{{cite web|title=Visy History|publisher=Visy|url=http://www.visy.com.au/?id=90|accessdate=29 April 2009}} ==Business career== Under Pratt's direction, Visy expanded from two factories in Melbourne to more than 55 plants across Australia, United States, New Zealand, and [[Papua New Guinea]]. From cardboard boxes and packaging, Visy moved into waste [[paper recycling]]. Later in the 1990s Pratt expanded his operations considerably into the [[New York (state)|New York]] waste paper business. In 1993 the [[National Crime Authority of Australia|National Crime Authority]] (NCA) raided Pratt's offices in connection with an investigation into businessman [[John Dorman Elliott|John Elliott]]'s foreign exchange dealings and Elliott's spoiling domestic stake in [[Broken Hill Proprietary Company]] (BHP, now BHP Billiton) while Elliott's company, [[Elders IXL]], was insolvent.{{cite news|title=Boxed-in billionaire|publisher=News.com.au|date=22 December 2005|work=The Australian|page=009|first=Richard |last=Gluyas}} The following year, NCA paid costs and returned documents seized.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2005/s1536457.htm|title=Richard Pratt faces damaging investigation|work=The World Today|date=22 December 2005|first=Edmond|last=Roy}} Also in the 1990s, Visy was ordered by the [[Australian Competition and Consumer Commission]] (ACCC) to pay a half million dollar fine for illegal anti-competitive behaviour.{{cite news|last=Washington|first=Stuart|title=Who really foots the bill for Pratt's philanthropy?|newspaper=The Age|date=13 October 2007|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/business/who-really-foots-the-bill-for-pratts-philanthropy/2007/10/12/1191696178506.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap2|accessdate=29 April 2009|location=Melbourne|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105170321/http://www.theage.com.au/news/business/who-really-foots-the-bill-for-pratts-philanthropy/2007/10/12/1191696178506.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap2|archivedate=5 November 2012}} ==Public career== As well as his business interests, Pratt was known for his involvement in public service, having held posts including: foundation chancellor of [[Swinburne University of Technology]], president of the [[Victorian Arts Centre]] Trust, and Chairman of the Board of Management of the [[Mental Health Research Institute (Melbourne)|Mental Health Research Institute of Victoria]].{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Through the [[Pratt Foundation]], the Pratt family are among Australia's leading philanthropists donating up to A$10 million a year. Pratt was named Environmental Visionary of the Year in 1998 by the Keep Australia Beautiful Campaign.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} On 8 February 2007 he was appointed president of the [[Carlton Football Club]]. On 20 June 2008, the Carlton Football Club announced that Richard Pratt would stand aside from the club until the charges of giving false and misleading evidence to [[Australian Competition and Consumer Commission]] hearing were resolved.{{cite news|last=Spits|first=Scott|title=Pratt stands aside as Carlton chief|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=20 June 2008|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/pratt-stands-aside-as-carlton-chief/2008/06/20/1213770889110.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303175553/http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/pratt-stands-aside-as-carlton-chief/2008/06/20/1213770889110.html|archivedate=3 March 2016|deadurl=no|accessdate=29 April 2009}} Pratt also donated considerable funds to both major political parties (for example A$300,000 in Financial Year 2004-5),{{cite web|title=Pratt Holdings Pty Ltd 2004/5|publisher=Australian Electoral Commission|url=http://fadar.aec.gov.au/Donor.aspx?SubmissionID=7&ClientID=21894|accessdate=12 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328172911/http://fadar.aec.gov.au/Donor.aspx?SubmissionID=7&ClientID=21894|archivedate=28 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} as well as to former [[Australian Prime Minister]] [[John Howard]]'s Liberal government.{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Katharine|title=Howard to keep Pratt's donations|newspaper=The Age|date=17 August 2007|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/federalelection2007/howard-to-keep-pratt-donations/2007/10/17/1192300841137.html|accessdate=29 April 2009|location=Melbourne|archivedate=5 November 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105170353/http://www.theage.com.au/news/federalelection2007/howard-to-keep-pratt-donations/2007/10/17/1192300841137.html}} In 1996 an investigation by ''[[The Australian]]'' newspaper documented from internal company documents that Pratt maintained a multimillion-dollar network of advisors. This included an $8,333.33 a month fee to [[Bob Hawke]] for consultation on "Asian and government matters", $27,220.03 for travel to the US for [[Gough Whitlam]] as business advisor on overseas markets, and other sums for former state premiers [[Nick Greiner]] and [[Rupert Hamer]]. ==Personal life== In 1959, Richard Pratt married Jeanne (née Lasker), a journalist, who was also a Jewish immigrant from Poland and was born in the town of lowich in Poland 1936, and before their marriage lived in Sydney.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/life-after-richard/story-e6frf7jo-1225890005828|newspaper=Herald Sun|publisher=News Limited|title=Life after Richard|date=10 July 2010|author=Plant, Simon|accessdate=19 June 2012}} After the success of Visy Industries, they enjoyed a lavish lifestyle, with a private jet and a range of apartments, including a penthouse at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel in New York City;{{cite news|last=Kirby|first=James|last2=Stephens|first2=Tony|title=Tycoon with an immense, combative energy|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=29 April 2009|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/obituaries/tycoon-with-an-immense-combative-energy-20090428-alzn.html?page=-1|accessdate=29 April 2009|archivedate=4 November 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104091313/http://www.smh.com.au/national/obituaries/tycoon-with-an-immense-combative-energy-20090428-alzn.html?page=-1}} their main home was the historic mansion [[Raheen (estate)|Raheen]], in the Melbourne suburb of [[Kew, Victoria|Kew]], the former residence of Roman Catholic Archbishop [[Daniel Mannix]]. The Pratts have had three children, [[Anthony Pratt (businessman)|Anthony]], Heloise Waislitz, who was married to businessman and Collingwood Football club Vice President [[Alex Waislitz]], and Fiona Geminder.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Another daughter, Paula, was born in 1997 to his longtime mistress, socialite Shari-Lea Hitchcock.{{cite news|last=Hornery|first=Andrew|last2=Cubby|first2=Ben|title=Space invaders|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=27 June 2005|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/spike/space-invaders/2005/06/26/1119724527096.html|accessdate=29 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106175242/http://www.smh.com.au/news/spike/space-invaders/2005/06/26/1119724527096.html|archivedate=6 November 2012}} In 2000 this affair became the subject of widespread media attention owing to a court case involving Ms Hitchcock and a nanny hired to look after her daughter. At the time, Pratt was accused of trying to pay hush money to the nanny who had launched legal action against Ms Hitchcock.{{cite news|title=Couple speak out on mistress|newspaper=The Australian|publisher=News Limited|date=7 August 2007|url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,22540312-2,00.html|accessdate=29 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504023357/http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,22540312-2,00.html|archivedate=4 May 2009}} Pratt was the godfather of Deborah Beale, who is the former wife of [[Bill Shorten]] and daughter of [[Julian Beale]].{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/mps-woes-pose-dilemma-for-billionaire/story-e6frg6nf-1111117577876|title=MP's marital woes pose dilemma for billionaire|newspaper=The Australian|publisher=News Limited|date=25 September 2008}} After a well-publicised battle with prostate cancer, Richard Pratt died at his Kew residence on 28 April 2009,{{cite news|title=billionaire Richard Pratt dies after prostate cancer battle|work=news.com.au|date=29 April 2009|url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,27574,25400857-421,00.html|accessdate=28 April 2009|archivedate=2 May 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502003023/http://www.news.com.au/story/0,27574,25400857-421,00.html|publisher=News Limited}} the day after all charges against him had been dropped due to his ill-health. ==Philanthropy== He donated A$10 million every year through the [[Pratt Foundation]] to refugees, artists and others.{{cite web|url=http://www.richardpratttribute.com/ |title=Visy – For a better World |website=Richardpratttribute.com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-15}} The Foundation was established in 1978 by Jeanne and Richard Pratt as a vehicle for their philanthropy. During the 1980s and 1990s, the Pratts became known in Australia for funding the arts, medical research and higher education. Since then the Pratt family has donated about A$200 million to worthy causes.{{cite press release|publisher=Swinburne Institute of Technology|url=http://www.swinburne.edu.au/chancellery/mediacentre/alumni/news/2011/08/jeanne-pratt-awarded-honorary-doctorate|title=Jeanne Pratt awarded honorary doctorate|date=2 August 2011|accessdate=19 June 2012}} ==Conviction for price fixing== In December 2005 the ACCC commenced a civil penalty proceeding against Visy companies, Pratt, and others, for alleged involvement in a [[cartel]] in the packaging industry.{{cite AustLII|FCA|2617|2007|litigants=Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Visy Industries Holdings Pty Limited (No 3) |courtname=auto}}. On 10 October 2007, Pratt was formally accused of [[price fixing]], cheating customers and companies out of approximately A$700 million in the nation's biggest-ever cartel case.{{cite news|last=Binnie|first=Craig|last2=Royall|first2=Ian|last3=Whinnett|first3=Ellen|last4=Mickelburough|first4=Peter|title=Richard Pratt cardboard deal may have cost $700m|publisher=Herald Sun|date=10 August 2007|url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,22560327-2862,00.html|accessdate=29 April 2009}} The ACCC alleged "very serious contraventions" of the law and that these had been "carefully and deliberately concealed" by Visy senior executives.{{cite news|last=Stewart|first=Cameron|title=Pratt buttoned up and beaten|publisher=News Limited|newspaper=The Australian|date=17 August 2007|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,22599836-601,00.html|accessdate=29 April 2009}} The ACCC counsel further stated:
''"There can be no suggestion that Visy acted in ignorance of its obligations under the act"{{cite news|last=Speedy|first=Blair|title=Watchdog puts $36m bite on Pratt|publisher=News Limited|newspaper=The Australian|date=17 August 2007|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,22599425-5013404,00.html|accessdate=29 April 2009}}
'' and further added that the deliberate use of pre-paid [[mobile phones]] that could not be traced and the holding of meetings in private homes, motel rooms and suburban parks ''
"...provides a strong indication that Visy was fully aware that the conduct was illegal".
'' After more than a year of denials Pratt subsequently admitted his guilt, acknowledging he and his company, and "rival" company [[Amcor]] deliberately broke the law.{{cite news|last=Stewart|first=Cameron|title=Richard Pratt to admit breaking law|publisher=News Limited|newspaper=The Australian|date=6 August 2007|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,22539478-601,00.html|accessdate=29 April 2009}} Pratt was aggrieved by the criminal prosecution and its effect on his reputation, stating: ''
"I feel very angry—Visy is seen as Richard Pratt's company—there is a certain amount of character assassination for me personally because I am a tall poppy in the community; it's a big scalp (for the ACCC). My reputation is something I have been building for 50 years and so I am worried that the general public will now see me as a rich person who has made his money doing something that is wrong in the eyes of the law."
'' On 2 November 2007, Pratt and the Visy group received an A$36 million fine, representing both the largest fine in Australian history and an estimated 0.75% of the Pratt fortune.{{cite news|title=Pratt, Visy fined $36m|publisher=News Limited|newspaper=Adelaide Now|date=2 November 2007|url=http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,22690569-911,00.html|accessdate=29 April 2009|archivedate=13 April 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080413015441/http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,22690569-911,00.html}}{{cite news|title=Visy in $300m cartel class action suit|publisher=NineMSN|date=29 November 2007|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=72669|accessdate=29 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226135241/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=72669|archivedate=26 February 2008|df=dmy-all}} [[Australian Federal Court|Federal Court]] judge Justice Heerey said Pratt and his senior executives were knowingly concerned in the cartel, which involved price fixing and market sharing. "''This is the worst cartel to come before the courts in 30-plus years''", Justice Heerey said. Additionally, customers of Visy initiated claims against Visy and Amcor, including a $120 million suit by [[Cadbury Schweppes]] against [[Amcor]]. ===Criminal prosecution for impropriety=== On 19 June 2008, Pratt was charged with lying about his knowledge of a price-fixing scandal.{{cite news|last=Ross|first=Norrie|work=Herald Sun|date=20 June 2008|url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,23892386-2862,00.html|accessdate=29 April 2009|title=Billionaire Dick Pratt faces jail}} Pratt had been facing four separate charges under Section 5 of the Act, the penalty for each charge ranges from a fine of $2,200 to 12 months' jail.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2008/s2281400.htm|title=Pratt pledges to fight charges|work=[[PM (ABC radio)]]|date=20 June 2008|first=Samantha|last=Donovan}} On 27 April 2009, this criminal prosecution of Pratt for charges of impropriety (lying to the ACCC during its successful investigation into the Visy/Amcor price fixing scandal) were abandoned on account of his poor health and impending death. However, Commonwealth Prosecutor Mark Dean SC told the Federal Court the [[Department of Public Prosecutions#Australia|Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions]] (CDPP) believed the prosecution would have succeeded.{{cite news|title=Prosecutor drops criminal charges against dying Richard Pratt|agency=Australian Associated Press|newspaper=The Australian|publisher=News Limited|date=27 April 2009|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/dpp-drops-charges-against-dying-pratt/story-e6frg6n6-1225704339699|accessdate=28 April 2009}} Pratt died the following day. ==Honours== Pratt was appointed an [[Officer of the Order of Australia]] (AO) in 1985, and a Companion of the Order (AC) in 1998. Jeanne Pratt is also an AC recipient.[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1040411&search_type=advanced&showInd=true Companion of the Order of Australia: PRATT, Jeanne], 10 June 2002. ''For outstanding leadership in the arts, for development of opportunities for young artistic talent on stage and in the orchestral field, and for service to the community through charitable and non-profit organisations.'' However, he returned his awards in February 2008 after he was fined $36 million for price fixing.{{cite web|title=Gazette, Special S 40|work=Commonwealth of Australia|publisher=Attorney-General's Department|date=22 February 2008|url=http://www.comlaw.gov.au/file/2008GN08|accessdate=2 July 2014}}[http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/pratt-gives-up-honours/story-e6frf7kx-1111115636502 "Billionaire Richard Pratt surrenders Order of Australia awards"], heraldsun.com.au, 25 February 2008. On 16 May 2007, he was awarded the [[Woodrow Wilson Awards#Woodrow Wilson Award for Corporate Citizenship|Woodrow Wilson Medal]] for [[Corporate Citizenship]].{{cite web|title=Woodrow Wilson Awards|publisher=Wilson Center|url=http://www.wilsoncenter.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=awards.awards|accessdate=29 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217065746/http://wilsoncenter.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=awards.awards|archivedate=17 February 2009|df=dmy-all}} This is given to executives who "by their examples and their business practices, have shown a deep concern for the common good beyond the bottom line. They are at the forefront of the idea that private firms should be good citizens in their own neighborhoods and in the world at large". In April 2010, to mark the first anniversary of his death, the inaugural Richard Pratt Memorial Oration was delivered at the [[University of Melbourne]] by the president of the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson. During the oration, Pratt was posthumously awarded an honorary Doctorate of Philosophy from Hebrew University.[http://newsroom.melbourne.edu/news/n-286 "Richard Pratt to be awarded posthumous honorary doctorate from Hebrew University of Jerusalem", University of Melbourne], melbourne.edu; accessed 13 September 2016. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [https://www.scribd.com/doc/4859766/Some-Inspirational-People-profiled-by-Laurence-MacDonald-Muir/ "Some Inspirational People"]; profiled by [[Sir Laurence Muir|Laurence MacDonald Muir]]. {{Business in Australia}} {{Morrish Medal}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pratt, Richard}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:Australian Jews]] [[Category:Polish Jews]] [[Category:Polish emigrants to Australia]] [[Category:Australian people of Polish-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Australian billionaires]] [[Category:Carlton Football Club administrators]] [[Category:Shepparton Swans Football Club players]] [[Category:Recycling industry]] [[Category:Former Companions of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Australian white-collar criminals]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Deaths from prostate cancer]] [[Category:People from Gdańsk]] [[Category:People from Shepparton]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Melbourne]] [[Category:People from the Free City of Danzig]] [[Category:Australian rules footballers from Victoria (Australia)]]

{{BLP sources|date=January 2009}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name = Sani Bello | image = | imagesize = | smallimage = | caption = | order = | office =[[List of Governors of Kano State|Governor]], [[Kano State]], [[Nigeria]] [[File:Seal of Kano.png|thumb|Seal of the Governor of the State of Kano]] | term_start =July 1975 | term_end =Sept 1978 | predecessor =Comm. of Police [[Audu Bako]] | successor =Group Captain [[Ishaya Aboi Shekari]] | party = None ( retired military officer) | birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1942|11|27|df=y}} | birth_place =[[Kontagora]], [[Niger State]], [[Nigeria]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality =[[Nigerian]] | spouse = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = Telecom/ Electricity Investor | profession = | religion =islam | website = | footnotes = |allegiance = {{flag|Nigeria}} |branch =<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Nigerian Army crest.gif|23px]] -->''[[Nigerian Army]]'' |rank = [[Colonel]] }} [[image:NigeriaKano.png|thumb|right|200px|[[Kano State]] in [[Nigeria]]]]
'''Sani Bello''' (born 27 November 1942) is a [[Nigeria]]n businessman and retired [[Military of Nigeria|Nigerian Army]] [[colonel]] and founder of the Sani Bello Foundation.<ref>Boboye Onduku.(2012) Investors Must Learn to Be Patient. Leadership (Abuja) November 27, 2012</ref>
==Early life and education== Sani Bello was born in 1942 at [[Kontagora]], [[Niger State]], the only child of Bello Mustapha and Hajiya Abu. He attended Central Primary School, Kotangora in 1950 and Government College, Bida {Niger State} in 1957, before joining the Nigerian Army in December 1962 as an officer [[Cadet]] at the Nigerian Military Training College, Kaduna. He attended [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]] in England and graduated as a [[Second Lieutenant|2nd Lieutenant]] in July 1965.
==Career== Following [[Officer (armed forces)|commission]] he returned to Nigeria and was posted to 1st Battalion, [[Enugu]] as a [[Platoon|Platoon Commander]]. He then held various posts in the Army as he progressed in ranks, including ADC to Major General [[Johnson Aguiyi-Ironsi]], Nigeria’s first military head of state. During the [[Nigerian Civil War]], he was a training officer at the 6th Battalion, Ikeja before he was posted to [[Kingdom of Bonny|Bonny]] as the Sector Commander.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sani Bello An Exceptional Entrepreneur|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Nigeria_federal_states.htm|work=Timothy Opaluwa|publisher=Leadership, Nigeria|date=5 December 2015}}</ref> During the war, Bello was wounded at Bonny and evacuated to Lagos for treatment, in Lagos, he served as a staff officer at the Lagos Garrison division. He was later posted to various commands including serving as Commander of the Oshodi Resettlement Center and Rear Commander of defunct Third Marine Commando division. He was also General Staff Officer and Assistant Quartermaster General of the 3rd Division. From 1971 to 1974, he was Deputy Adjutant General of the Nigerian army before becoming the Commanding Officer of the 81 Battalion, Kaduna. He retired from the Nigerian army as a Principal Staff Officer.
===Military Administrator of Kano=== Sani Bello was also a Military Governor of the old [[Kano State]] from 1975 – 1978.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nigeria States|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Nigeria_federal_states.htm|work=Ben Cahoon|publisher=worldstatesmen.org|date=11 November 2010}}</ref> During his tenure, he focused on commerce, rural roads, electrification and primary and secondary education. In 1976, he developed a Science Secondary School Management Board establishing science colleges to train Kano State residents and give them the opportunity to qualify for science courses at the university level also to climb to middle and top level grades in the government.<ref>Danyaro, M. M. (1998). Kano State: 30 years of statehood. Kano State, Nigeria: publisher not identified.</ref> Notable schools established during the period are Dawakin Kudu and Dawakin Tofa Science schools. His administration was also tasked to implement two key Federal programmes: local government reform and universal primary education. Local government reform led to the creation of 20 [[Local government areas of Nigeria|local government areas]] in Kano.
Alfa Wali, Balarabe Ismail were SMGs in the administration, Abdu Sambo and [[Abdullahi Aliyu Sumaila]] served as the scribes (Secretary to the Executive Council) to his government.Umaru Abdulwahab was the Principal Secretary to the Governor
===Business career=== After retirement in 1979, Colonel Bello held various part-time appointments as a chairman of Niger State Green Revolution, Niger State NYSC, Niger State Polytechnic and Niger State Science and Technical School Board. He also served as Nigerian [[High Commissioner]] (Ambassador) to Zimbabwe from 1984- 1986.
On his return home from Zimbabwe Bello became involved with various companies as chairman or director, including former Broadbank Nigeria Ltd, Globe Re Nigeria Ltd, Law Union and [[Skye Bank|Rock Insurance Company Plc]], Dantata and Sawoe Construction Company Ltd, [[MTN Group|MTN Communications Ltd]], Equatel Communication Ltd, President of National Association of Indigenous Petroleum Explorers in Nigeria and Mainstream Energy Solutions ltd Nigeria. He is also a farmer and Proprietor of [[Mustafa]] Comprehensive School, [[Kontagora]]. He is a co-founder of Amni International Petroleum Development Company Ltd that has interest in Ketu and Okoro oilfields.
He is a passionate lover of sports, especially table tennis in which he once served as the Chairman of Nigerian Table Tennis Federation and led the national team to the [[Commonwealth]] and World Championships in 1983.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Governors of Kano State}} {{Nigeria Murtala Governors}}
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox newspaper | name = Stears Business | logo =https://stears.s3.amazonaws.com/static/library/img/logos/stears-business-coloured.svg | image = | caption = | type = Daily | format = Online | founder = <!-- or |founders= --> | publisher = Stears | editor = | president = | chiefeditor =Michael Famoroti | depeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = <!-- or |launched= --> <!-- Use: {{start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | political = | language = English | ceased publication = | relaunched = | headquarters = | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = {{url|https://www.stearsng.com}} | free = | dirinteractive = | circulation_ref = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | image_size = | image_alt = | motto = | owner = <!-- or |owners= --> | generalmanager = | metroeditor = | metrochief = | publishing_city = Lagos, London | publishing_country = Nigeria | circulation_date = | readership = | RNI = }} '''''Stears Business''''' is a [[Newspapers published in Nigeria|Nigerian business publication]] based between Lagos and London with a focus on business, economic and political news. ''Stears Business'' is published by Stears and its journalists are predominantly based in Lagos. As of September 2017, the Editor-in-Chief was Michael Famoroti.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/nigerias-government-announced-074341502.html/?ref=gs|title=Nigeria gets cabinet ministers after long wait|access-date=2017-03-17|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gallery.cnbcafrica.com/video/?bctid=5131372449001|title=S&P downgrades Nigeria further into junk|website=CNBCAfrica.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-17}}</ref>
The publication takes a neutral editorial stance in its analysis of government, free trade and globalisation as it believes in 'the value of permitting all inoffensive ideologies in informing debate'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stearsng.com/about-us#about-stears|title=About - Stears News|website=www.stearsng.com|access-date=2017-03-17}}</ref> The editorial board is composed of alumni of the [[London School of Economics]] and is particularly focused on Africa.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/africaatlse/2015/08/11/the-state-of-our-finances/|title=The State of Nigeria’s Finances|date=2015-08-11|work=Africa at LSE|access-date=2017-03-17|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lseafricasummit.org/partners/|title=Partners|website=LSE Africa Summit 2017|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-17}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{primarysources|date=May 2009}}
'''The Committee of 200''' is an invitation only [[membership organization]] of the world's most successful women [[entrepreneur]]s and corporate leaders. The Committee of 200's more than 450 members represent over 100 industries in the [[United States|U.S.]], [[Europe]], [[Asia]], [[Canada]] and [[Latin America]] and its members generate more than $200 billion in annual revenues.<ref>{{cite web|title=Joyce Russel Inducted to The Committee of 200|url=http://www.adeccousa.com/articles/Joyce-Russel-Inducted-to-the-Committee-of-200.html?id=118&url=/pressroom/pressreleases/Archives/Forms/AllItems.aspx&templateurl=/AboutUs/pressroom/Pages/Press-release.aspx}}</ref>
==History==
In 1982, a handful of the most powerful [[women in business]] gathered in [[Los Angeles]]. Their immediate goal was to raise funds for The [[National Association of Women Business Owners]], a network dedicated to women entrepreneurs. Beyond raising $200,000 for NAWBO, the small group of women ultimately conceived a larger agenda: to create a national network that would capitalize on the experience of women at the top echelons of business.<ref>{{cite web|title=NNBD|url=http://www.nndb.com/org/771/000128387/}}</ref>
==Present day==
The primary mission of C200 is success shared: to foster, celebrate and advance women's leadership in business. C200 members are uniquely connected to each other through the organization by the commonality of their careers. C200 offers current leaders access to unique programming plus a professional and personal network of their peers.
The committee takes part in reach out programs across the United States and in other select areas to MBA and college students as well as high school students. In the past they've visited colleges such as [[Stanford University]], [[Tel Aviv University]], [[University of California Los Angeles]], [[Duke University]], [[University of Chicago]], and [[London Business School]]. C200 has also visited with high schools such as [[The Ann Richards School for Young Women Leaders|The Ann Richards School]] and [[The Young Women's Leadership School of East Harlem]].<ref>https://www.c200.org/C200/Our_Foundation/Campus_Reachouts/C200/Our_Foundation/Campus_Reachouts.aspx?hkey=9e6956be-602a-4b8a-b8c0-7044fd7e0473</ref>
==C200 Foundation==
In 1987, C200 launched the C200 Foundation to provide women with tools to become successful entrepreneurs and corporate leaders. C200 co-sponsors one-day Reachouts for women MBA students. Seminars rotate among the nation’s top [[business school]]s, and at the seminar they award C200 Scholar Awards to enterprising first year women MBAs enrolled at the hosting school.<ref>{{cite web|title=bizologie: The Committee of 200|url=http://www.bizologie.com/c200-the-committee-of-200/}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.c200.org The Committee of 200 website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Committee Of 200, The}} [[Category:Organizations for women in business]]

{{Infobox film | name = The Solid Gold Cadillac | image_size = | image = The Solid Gold Cadillac FilmPoster.jpeg | caption = | director = [[Richard Quine]] | producer = [[Fred Kohlmar]] | based on = {{based on|''The Solid Gold Cadillac''
1953 play|[[George S. Kaufman]]
[[Howard Teichmann]]}} | writer = [[Abe Burrows]] | narrator = [[George Burns]] | starring = [[Judy Holliday]]
[[Paul Douglas (actor)|Paul Douglas]] | music = [[Cyril J. Mockridge]] | cinematography = [[Charles Lang]] | editing = Charles Nelson | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = {{start date|1956|8|22}} | runtime = 99 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $2.4 million (US)"Top Grosses of 1957", ''Variety'', 8 January 1958: 30 }} '''''The Solid Gold Cadillac''''' is a 1956 film directed by [[Richard Quine]] and written by [[Abe Burrows]], [[Howard Teichmann]] and [[George S. Kaufman]]. It was adapted from the hit [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] play of the same name by Teichmann and Kaufman, in which they pillory [[big business]] and corrupt businessmen. The film stars [[Judy Holliday]] and [[Paul Douglas (actor)|Paul Douglas]]. The film is in black-and-white except for the very last scene, which is in [[Technicolor]]. ==Plot== At a [[shareholder]]s meeting for International Projects, a billion dollar corporation, John T. Blessington ([[John Williams (actor)|John Williams]]) announces that he is replacing Edward L. McKeever ([[Paul Douglas]]), the company's founder, President and Chairman of the Board, who is resigning to work for the federal government in [[Washington D.C.]] Laura Partridge ([[Judy Holliday]]), a minority [[stockholder]] with just ten shares of stock, drives its arrogant, self-serving executives to distraction with her incessant questioning during this and subsequent meetings. Blessington comes up with the idea of hiring the struggling actress as Director of Shareholder Relations to keep her occupied answering letters from small shareholders. He assigns her a secretary, Amelia Shotgraven ([[Neva Patterson]]), with secret instructions to obstruct her as much as possible. The conscientious Miss Partridge, discovering there is nothing for her to do, decides to write the stockholders herself. She gains Amelia's friendship and wholehearted assistance by helping her develop a romantic relationship with office manager Mark Jenkins ([[Arthur O'Connell]]). When the directors find out, they fire Amelia. However, Laura discovers that Blessington's thoroughly unqualified brother-in-law, Harry Harkness ([[Hiram Sherman]]), has driven a competitor into bankruptcy, unaware that International Projects actually owns the unfortunate company. With that as leverage, she gets Amelia rehired. Still determined to neutralize Laura, the Board decides to send her to Washington to persuade McKeever to give them some government contracts. She agrees to go, with the secret intention of trying to convince him to return and take back control from his crooked cronies. However, the company Directors recall that he has divested himself of all his shares and is thus powerless, so they brush him off. McKeever takes them to court, arguing that Laura was an unlicensed, illegal lobbyist; but, when she is forced to admit on the stand that she had another, romantic, reason for seeing him, the case is dropped. However, Laura has forged a warm relationship with many of the smaller investors while working at the company; they responded and sent in their [[Proxy voting|proxies]], giving her the right to vote their shares. McKeever uses these votes to replace the entire Board. He marries Laura. As a gift to "The Girl Who Has Everything," her husband presents her a Solid Gold Cadillac for her birthday. ==Cast== * [[Judy Holliday]] as Laura Partridge * [[Paul Douglas (actor)|Paul Douglas]] as Edward L. McKeever * [[Fred Clark]] as Clifford Snell, the company treasurer * [[John Williams (actor)|John Williams]] as John T. Blessington * [[Hiram Sherman]] as Harry Harkness * [[Neva Patterson]] as Amelia Shotgraven * [[Ralph Dumke]] as Warren Gillie, a director * [[Ray Collins (actor)|Ray Collins]] as Alfred Metcalfe, another director * [[Arthur O'Connell]] as Mark Jenkins * [[Harry Antrim]] as Senator Simpkins * [[George Burns]] as narrator ==Reception== [[Bosley Crowther]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised Holliday highly, stating, "the invincible Miss Holliday has dared to project her youthful figure and personality into the character shaped by Miss Hull" ([[Josephine Hull]], then in her seventies, played the role in the Broadway play) and is "knocking the role completely dead."{{cite news |title=The Solid Gold Cadillac (1956) |author=Bosley Crowther |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 25, 1956 |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?_r=2&res=9E0DE1DE1138E033A05756C2A9669D946792D6CF&partner=Rotten%20Tomatoes}} However, he felt that the villains of the piece were neither particularly convincing ("not precisely representatives of the workaday financial world"), original ("cut from a fairly familiar stencil of Kaufmanesque farce"), or formidable enough ("The problems set up by the play-wrights are little barriers of cardboard farce"). He concluded, "it will give you an entertaining ride, but don't expect it to take you or your intelligence very far." The [[Film4]] reviewer agreed that the story was not particularly convincing ("Yeah – like global capitalism gets overthrown that easily"), but "even so, it's undemanding and amusing."{{cite web |url=http://www.film4.com/reviews/1956/solid-gold-cadillac-the |title=Solid Gold Cadillac, The |accessdate=March 1, 2010}} ==Awards and nominations== [[Jean Louis]] won the [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Costume Design|Best Costume Design Black and White]]. [[Ross Bellah]], [[William Kiernan]], and [[Louis Diage]] were nominated for the Academy Award for [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Best Art Direction Black and White]].{{cite web |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/110888/The-Solid-Gold-Cadillac/details |title=NY Times: The Solid Gold Cadillac |accessdate=2008-12-22|work=NY Times}} Holliday was nominated for the [[Golden Globe Award]] for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]], while the film was nominated for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy]]. ==See also== *[[List of American films of 1956]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0049777}} * {{amg title|id=110888}} * {{tcmdb title|id= 53021}} * {{AFI film|id=52008|title=The Solid Gold Cadillac}} {{Richard Quine}} {{Abe Burrows}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Solid Gold Cadillac, The}} [[Category:1956 films]] [[Category:1950s romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American business films]] [[Category:American romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American films based on plays]] [[Category:Films directed by Richard Quine]] [[Category:Films scored by Cyril J. Mockridge]] [[Category:Films set in New York City]] [[Category:Films set in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Films that won the Best Costume Design Academy Award]]

{{for|other people called Thomson Mason|Thomson Mason (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox person|name = Thomson Mason |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Thomson Mason |birth_date = {{Birth date|1733|08|14}} |birth_place = [[Chopawamsic (plantation)|Chopawamsic]], [[Stafford County, Virginia|Stafford County]], [[Colony of Virginia]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1785|02|26|1733|08|14}} |death_place = Chopawamsic, Stafford County, [[Virginia]] |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = [[Chopawamsic (plantation)|Chopawamsic]], Stafford County, Virginia
[[Raspberry Plain]], [[Leesburg, Virginia|Leesburg]], Virginia |nationality = American |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = [[The College of William & Mary|College of William and Mary]] |employer = |occupation = [[lawyer]], [[jurist]], Chief Justice of the [[Supreme Court of Virginia]], planter |years_active = |home_town = |networth = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |spouse = Mary King Barnes
Elizabeth Westwood Wallace |children = [[Stevens Thomson Mason (Virginia)|Stevens Thomson Mason]]
Abram Barnes Thomson Mason
[[John Thomson Mason]]
Ann Thomson Mason Chichester
Dorothea Anna Thomson Mason Hirst
Westwood Thomson Mason
[[William Temple Thomson Mason]]
George Thomson Mason |parents = [[George Mason III]]
Ann Stevens Thomson |relations = brother of [[George Mason|George Mason IV]] }} '''Thomson Mason''' (14 August 1733{{spaced ndash}}26 February 1785){{cite web | url=http://www.gunstonhall.org/masonweb/p26.htm#i1267 | title=Thomson Mason | date=| accessdate=2008-02-15 | website=gunstonhall.org | publisher=Gunston Hall |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080211141639/http://www.gunstonhall.org/masonweb/p26.htm#i1267 |archivedate = 2008-02-11}} was a prominent [[Virginia]] [[lawyer]], [[jurist]], and Chief Justice of the [[Supreme Court of Virginia]].{{cite web | url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/families/10855.html | title=Mason family of Virginia | date= June 16, 2008| accessdate=2008-02-15 | website=politicalgraveyard.com | publisher=The Political Graveyard}} Mason was a younger brother of [[George Mason|George Mason IV]], [[United States]] [[Patriot (American Revolution)|patriot]], statesman, and delegate from [[Virginia]] to the U.S. Constitutional Convention, father of [[Stevens Thomson Mason (Virginia)|Stevens Thomson Mason]], a Colonel in the [[Continental Army]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]], a member of the [[Virginia]] state legislature, and a [[U.S. Senator]] from Virginia, and great-grandfather of [[Stevens T. Mason]], first [[Governor of Michigan]]. ==Early life== Mason was born at [[Chopawamsic (plantation)|Chopawamsic]] in [[Stafford County, Virginia|Stafford County]], [[Virginia]] on 14 August 1733. He was the third and youngest child of [[George Mason III]] and his wife Ann Stevens Thomson. ==Career== Mason was educated at the [[College of William & Mary]] in [[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]], Virginia{{cite book| last = [[The Colonial Dames of America]] | title =Ancestral Records and Portraits: A Compilation from the Archives of Chapter I, the Colonial Dames of America | publisher =Grafton Press | year= 1910 | location =[[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] | pages=808}} and then studied law at the [[Middle Temple]] in [[London]].{{cite web | url=http://virtualology.com/revolutionarywarhall/georgemason.net/ | title=George Mason: Statesman | year=2000 | accessdate=2008-02-15 | publisher=Virtual War Museum | author=Evisum Inc.}} Afterwards, he returned to Virginia and was a [[burgess (title)|burgess]] in the [[House of Burgesses]] representing [[Stafford County, Virginia|Stafford]] and [[Loudoun County, Virginia|Loudoun]] counties from 1766 to 1775. In 1778, Mason was appointed Chief Justice of the [[Supreme Court of Virginia]] and served only briefly before serving as one of five judges in the General Court. From 1779 to 1783, Mason was elected a member of the [[Virginia House of Delegates]] and served as chairman of the Committee on Courts of Justice. ==Raspberry Plain== In 1760, Mason purchased [[Raspberry Plain]] in [[Loudoun County, Virginia]]{{cite web | url=http://www.raspberryplain.com/ | title=Raspberry Plain: History | date= | accessdate=2009-02-15 | website=raspberryplain.com | publisher=Raspberry Plain}} In 1771, Thomson built the mansion at Raspberry Plain. Upon Thomson's death, the Raspberry Plain estate was deeded to his eldest son [[Stevens Thomson Mason (Virginia)|Stevens Thomson Mason]].{{cite web|url=http://www.huntcountrycelebrations.com/receptionSites.html |title=Hunt Country Celebrations: Reception Sites |year=2008 |accessdate=2009-02-15 |website=huntcountrycelebrations.com |publisher=Hunt Country Celebrations |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827203339/http://huntcountrycelebrations.com/receptionSites.html |archivedate=August 27, 2008 }} ==Marriages and children== Mason married Mary King Barnes, the only daughter of Colonel Abraham Barnes and his wife Mary King, in 1758. He and Mary had four children: *[[Stevens Thomson Mason (Virginia)|Stevens Thomson Mason]] (29 December 1760–9 May 1803) *Abram Barnes Thomson Mason (24 August 1763–12 January 1813) *[[John Thomson Mason]] (15 March 1765–10 December 1824) *Ann Thomson Mason Chichester (26 February 1769–29 August 1817) Mary died on 21 October 1771 in [[Prince William County, Virginia|Prince William County]], Virginia and was interred in the Mason family graveyard at [[Gunston Hall]] and later moved to Raspberry Plain. Six years later on 23 November 1777, Mason married for a second time to Elizabeth Westwood Wallace. He and Elizabeth had four children: *Dorothea "Anne" Anna Thomson Mason Hirst (10 April 1778–5 May 1822) *Westwood Thomson Mason (20 December 1780–1826) *[[William Temple Thomson Mason]] (24 July 1782–1862) *George Thomson Mason (died 1873) ==Later life== Mason died on 26 February 1785 at Chopawamsic at the age of 51. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Virginia Masons}} {{George Mason}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mason, Thomson}} [[Category:1733 births]] [[Category:1785 deaths]] [[Category:18th-century American Episcopalians]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American planters]] [[Category:British North American Anglicans]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Virginia]] [[Category:Chief Justices of the Virginia Supreme Court]] [[Category:George Mason]] [[Category:House of Burgesses members]] [[Category:Mason family]] [[Category:People from Leesburg, Virginia]] [[Category:People from Stafford County, Virginia]] [[Category:College of William & Mary alumni]] [[Category:Virginia lawyers]]

{{about||the Norwegian gymnast Thor Jensen|Thor Jensen}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}}
[[File:Thor Jensen and Margrét Þorbjörg Kristjánsdóttir.png|thumb|A relief of Thor Jensen and Margrét Þorbjörg Kristjánsdóttir by Sigurjón Ólafsson from the memorial in Hallargarður, Reykjavík.]]
'''Thor Philip Axel Jensen''' (3 December 1863 – 12 September 1947) was a [[Danes|Danish]] [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]] who moved to [[Iceland]] at an early age and became famous there for his business activities during the first half of the twentieth century: he all but introduced big business, and even modern capitalism, to the country. His company Kveldúlfur hf. was the biggest in Iceland during the inter-war years. His descendants include some of Iceland's most powerful and well known figures.
==Early life==
Thor's father, Jens Chr. Jensen, was a master builder. Thor had eleven siblings and four half-sisters. Thor did well in his studies but lost his father at the age of eight. Two years later, he was sent to a free boarding school for orphans in [[Copenhagen]]. In 1878, at the end of his studies and after reaching confirmation age, Thor was sent to [[Borðeyri]], a small trading settlement in the north-west of Iceland, because his headmaster knew an Icelandic merchant there.
Thor adapted quickly to Iceland, learning [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]] and reading [[Sagas of Icelanders|medieval Icelandic sagas]]. A certain widow moved to Borðeyri with two children in tow—a boy and a girl. The girl was called [[Margrét Þorbjörg Kristjánsdóttir]]; she and Thor fell in love, and remained together for over sixty years, having twelve children.
==Businesses== [[File:Fríkirkjuvegur 11.png|thumb|The house originally built in 1908 by Thor Philip Axel Jensen, Fríkirkjuvegur 11, Reykjavík, Iceland.]] Thor and Margrét moved to [[Akranes]] where Thor started a shop. Business went well at first, but around 1900 Thor was bankrupted when a ship carrying his goods was lost. Thor moved with his family to [[Hafnarfjörður]] where they lived until Thor got back on his feet and established a new shop in [[Reykjavík]]. Fishing at this time in Iceland was in transition from being 'a secondary occupation for farmers' to being 'an industry in its own right'.<ref>Valdimar Tr. Hafstein, 'The Elves' Point of View: Cultural Identity in Contemporary Icelandic Elf-Tradition', ''Fabula: Zeitschrift für Erzählsforschung/Journal of Folklore Studies/Revue d'Etudes sur le Conte Populaire'', 41 (2000), 87-104, p. 95.</ref> Thor was known for his energy and 'two of the most powerful fishing businessmen in Seltjarnarnes, Guðmundur Einarsson í Nesi and Þórður Jónasson í Ráðagerði, said that they would buy fishing equipment from him if he offered it at a competitive price'.<ref>'[t]veir af öflugustu útvegsbændum á Seltjarnarnesi, Guðmundur Einarsson í Nesi og Þórður Jónasson í Ráðagerði sögðust skildu kaupa af honum útgerðarvörur ef hann byði þær á samkeppnishæfu verði', Guðmundur Magnússon. ''Thorsararnir'', p. 37.</ref> Guðmundur gave Thor the use of his premises on the corner of Austurstræti and Veltusund in Reykjavík, and both he and Þórður invested 500 krónur to start the company. Thor called the company Godthaab-verzlunin after the street Godthaabsvej in [[Frederiksberg]] in Copenhagen. The company did well and Thor was soon the richest person in Iceland. In 1908 he built himself a splendid house at Fríkirkjuvegur 11, by [[Tjörnin]], now in the Hallargarður sculpture park.
With Pétur J. Thorsteinsson, Thor was a founder member of the fishing and fish-processing company PJ Thorsteinsson & Co, otherwise known as the [[Milljónarfélagið]], in 1907. The company's name came about because it aimed to achieve a share capital of ISK1m, which would have equalled Iceland's state budget---though that goal was never quite achieved. Through it, Thor took a role in the design of the Jóni forseti, Iceland's first trawler; established a harbour at [[Viðey]]; and built Iceland's only railway line. Pétur and Thor got on badly; Pétur left, and four years later, the company was bankrupt; both partners lost money, but Pétur the more. 'At the time, there was an investigation into the affair, where Jensen famously couldn’t remember a thing about the whole debacle.' Later, in his autobiography, Jensen argued, implausibly, that the bankruptcy was in no way his fault.<ref>http://uti.is/2011/08/historical-parallels-in-the-thor%E2%80%99s-saga/</ref> He was also a founder member of [[Eimskip]] but was not elected to the board on account of his origins, and took no further role in the company.
In later years Thor focused on making Korpúlfsstaður the largest dairy in Iceland. He put considerable resources behind this and achieved his goal. Thor died one night after a stroke. Out of respect, his numerous businesses closed the day of his funeral, which took place on 18 September 1947.<ref>http://www.timarit.is/?issueID=410669&pageSelected=6&lang=0: 'Fjöldi tilkynninga frá fyrirtækjum', ''Morgunblaðið'', 18 September 1947.</ref>
==Land purchases==
Thor became noted for buying up large tracts of land.<ref>Roger Boyes, Meltdown Iceland: Lessons on the World Financial Crisis from a Small Bankrupt Island (New York: Bloomsbury, 2009), p. 63.</ref> According to his autobiography, he aspired to own all the lands supposedly claimed on [[Snæfellsnes]] by the ninth-century settler [[Bjǫrn the Easterner]], so as to follow in the footsteps of the ''[[Settlement of Iceland|landnámsmenn]]''. Thus in 1914, he bought Bjarnarhöfn, along with various uninhabited plots and islands: Guðnýjarstaðir, Efrakot, Neðrakot, Hrútey, Hafnareyjar, and the inhabited Ármýrar, for 18,000 krónur. In the following years, he bought the neighbouring Fjarðarhorn, Árnabotn, Hraunsfjörð, Selvelli, Seljahraun and Kothraun. He used these lands for sheep farming. Thor also bought lands at [[Borgarnes]].<ref>Guðmundur Magnússon, Thorsararnir: auður – völd – örlög (Reykjavík: Almenna bókafélagið, 2005), p. 146.</ref>
From 1909, Thor began buying up land and fishing rights along the Haffjarðará, one of Iceland's most famed salmon rivers, until he owned all the fishing on the river. The river became the focus of his family's summer holidays, and for line-fishing by paying visitors.<ref>Guðmundur Magnússon, Thorsararnir: auður – völd – örlög (Reykjavík: Almenna bókafélagið, 2005), p. 146.</ref>
==Descendants==
Thor and Margrét had twelve children, and together the parents and children are known in Icelandic as the ''Thorsararnir''; they and their descendents include some of Iceland's most prominent figures, chronicled by Guðmundur Magnússon.<ref>''Thorsararnir: auður – völd – örlög'' (Reykjavík: Almenna bókafélagið, 2005).</ref> The children were: Camilla Therese (20 April 1887 – 1968), Richard (29 April 1888 – 1970), Kjartan (26 April 1890 – 1971), [[Ólafur Thors|Ólafur (Tryggvason)]] (19 January 1892 – 1964), Haukur (21 March 1896 – 1970), Kristín (16 February 1899 – 1972), Kristjana (23 July 1900 – 1989), [[Margrét Þorbjörg Thors Hallgrímsson|Margrét Þorbjörg]] (22 April 1902 – 1996), [[Thor Thors|Thor (Harald)]] (26 November 1903 – 1965), Lorentz (4 July 1904 – 1970), Louise Andrea (24 August 1906 – 1907), and (Louis) Hilmar (7 July 1908 – 1939).<ref>http://www.arnastofnun.is/page/aettarnofn_a_islandi; 'Margrét Þorbjörg Thors', ''Morgunblaðið'', 10 September 1996, http://www.mbl.is/greinasafn/grein/286017/.</ref>
Thor's son [[Ólafur Thors]] was Iceland's prime minister five times; Ólafur's daughter [[Margrét Þorbjörg Thors]] was married to the pilot [[Tony Jonsson]]; another son, [[Thor Thors]], was Iceland's first Permanent Representative to the United Nations. His grandchildren include Elina Hallgrímsdottir, [[Margrét Þóra Hallgrímsson]], wife of [[Björgólfur Guðmundsson]] and mother of [[Björgólfur Thor Björgólfsson]]; and the author [[Thor Vilhjálmsson]], whose son [[Guðmundur Andri Thorsson]] is also a noted author.
For the most part, the period of the greatest power, wealth, and influence of the Thorsararnir had run its course by the 1970s, though the descendants of Thor and Margrét now number several hundred.<ref>Guðmundur Magnússon, ''Thorsararnir: auður – völd – örlög'' (Reykjavík: Almenna bókafélagið, 2005), p. 353.</ref>
==Appearances in popular culture==
Thor Jensen and his great-grandson [[Björgólfur Thor Björgólfsson]] are the subject of the 2011 documentary film ''Thor's Saga'' by Ulla Boje Rasmussen.<ref>http://www.upfrontfilms.dk/films2.php?mit_indhold_id=2&films_id=13</ref>
==References==
{{Reflist}}
==Sources== * Guðmundur Magnússon, ''Thorsararnir: auður - völd - örlög'' (Almenna bókafélagið, 2006); {{ISBN|9979219912}} * 'Thor Jensen látinn', ''Morgunblaðið'', 13 September 1947, http://www.timarit.is/view_page_init.jsp?pageId=1264783 * 'Thor Jensen - minninarorð', ''Morgunblaðið'', 18 September 1947, http://timarit.is/view_page_init.jsp?pageId=1264843 * 'Thor Jensen - hinn síðasti mikli landnámsmaður', ''Morgunblaðið'', 3 December 1963, http://www.timarit.is/view_page_init.jsp?pageId=1354486 * ''Rithöfundur til varnar langafa. Ekkert líkt með Thor Jensen og Björgólfi Guðmundssyni''; from Eyjunni.is: http://eyjan.is/blog/2009/08/05/rithofundur-til-varnar-langafa-ekkert-likt-med-thor-jensen-og-bjorgolfi
{{DEFAULTSORT:Jensen, Thor Philip Axel}} [[Category:Icelandic businesspeople]] [[Category:1863 births]] [[Category:1947 deaths]]
